p: On the basis of surface antigens, there are four genera of this family: types A, B, C, and thogotovirus. Influenza A and B are the predominant pathogen in seasonal influenza, while influenza virus A is most severe than influenza virus B and may cause severe influenza. Influenza type C infections are generally responsible for mild respiratory illness and could not cause epidemics. Influenza D viruses mainly affect cattle and are not found to infest on humans or cause illness in them.
